page.title: 14AN ARABLE FARM IN WADDINGTON
page.content: Lowfields Farm covers 520 acres. It is owned by two brothers, one of whom independantly runs a 20 sow pig unit and fattens a few beef cattle. In 1985 the farm grew 200 acres of wheat, 160 of barley, 40 of rape, 52 of sugar beet, 30 of protein peas and a few acres of potatoes. Sugar beet was the most profitable crop. The price for potatoes did not justify the effort. One of the brothers' sons works on the farm, the other having become a gamekeeper. A daughter works there as part of a Y.T.S. scheme. There are no other workers, though one of the wives does the book-keeping. Every day is different depending on the season but each working day lasts at least from 8.00am to 8.00pm. The most important factor is the weather since it is one of the few things the farmer cannot control.
